Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer committed a reviewable error in rejecting the application
Application_Facts: Applicant applied as a skilled worker; Officers substituted judgment under subsections 76(3) and 76(4); settlement funds were not considered; marital status was improperly deemed irrelevant
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to quash the decision and remit for re-determination
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review allowed; decision quashed and remitted
Defendant_Behavior: Officer failed to consider key settlement factors; second Officer misapplied relevance of marital status
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consider relevant factors, consideration of irrelevant factors, unreasonable decision-making
Applicable_Legislation: Subsections 76(3) and 76(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness in assessment
Application_Basis: Skilled worker category under federal economic class
Relief_Sought: Quashing of decision and re-determination by a different officer
Governing_Rule: Officers may substitute judgment if points do not reflect ability to settle, but must consider all relevant factors
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remitted for new assessment
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of immigration opportunity due to flawed evaluation
Cause_Description: Applicant's skilled worker application was rejected due to substituted evaluation by Officers who failed to properly assess settlement ability
Evidence_Handling: Key evidence (settlement funds) overlooked; marital status incorrectly dismissed
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsections 76(3) and 76(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Provision: Subsections 76(3) and 76(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Decision_Rationale: Officer exercised substituted judgment without considering mandatory factors, leading to unreasonable outcome
Evidentiary_Issues: Improper dismissal of marital status as irrelevant
